instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight / <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pads corroded and gone.
threads.message: As the title says, this is a board that came in with liquid damage, upon cleaning both resistors came off the board, with little force, and the pads are gone too. I know I will have to run a wire to ball 3 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, my question is how much voltage is on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>, and what could I leach off of to supply that voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight / <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pads corroded and gone.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is exactly 1/3 of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
It varies, depending of battery level; at least 2V needed there,no more than 3.42V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight / <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pads corroded and gone.
threads.message:
Ok, so should I run a wire from <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> (3.3V) to <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> (A3)?

I cant fine any 2V source, and this was the closest source of 3.3V.

EDIT: <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight / <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pads corroded and gone.
threads.message: You can do that, if no way to rebuild the original traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight / <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pads corroded and gone.
threads.message:
Original traces are gone for <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>, however for <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> just the ground pad is somewhat OK.

Thank you I will run a wire and report back.
